bibl.title: Letter from Harold M. Randall to Robert F. Woodward, October 19, 1954 [Enclosed in 04724010]

div1.p: Randall clarifies that it was the Venezuelans, not the French, who tried to get Beauperthuy credit for discovering that the mosquito transmitted yellow fever. The XIV International Congress of the History of Medicine passed a resolution in favor of Finlay.

div1.head: Letter from Harold M. Randall to Robert F. Woodward, October 19, 1954 [Enclosed in 04724010]
div1.opener:
American Embassy,
Habana, Cuba,
October 19, 1954.
Dear Bob:
div1.p:
I have your letter of October 8 regarding the
matter of Carlos J. Finlay's discovery of the yellow
fever vector together with its enclosure of Dr. Hench's
letter of October 5. I appreciate very much the way
you handled our request and Dr. Hench's offer of
cooperation at the medical congress. Accordingly, I
am more than apologetic when I find myself obliged
to write you that I was misinformed as to the date of
the congress and that it has already taken place.

The congres in question was the XIV International
Congress of the History of Medicine and was held in
Rome in mid-September. It was the Venezuelans, not
the French, who were interested in proving that a Franco-
Venezuelan physician and not Finlay had discovered that
Aedes Aegvpti transmitted yellow fever. However, it's
my impression from the press reports that while there
had been articles along this line in the Venezuelan
press in the early summer, the Venezuelans did not press,
or at least did not press vigorously, a claim for
Beauperthuy at the congress itself.

In any event, the Cubans succeeded in having a
resolution unaminously passed which, in Spanish, reads:

“Que el XIV Congreso Internacional de
Historia de la Medicina, con sede en Roma-
Salerno, Italia, ratifica, una vez más, que
sólo al doctor Carlos J. Finlay, de Cuba,
y sólo a él, corresponde el descubrimiento
del agente transmisor de la fiebre amarilla
y a la aplicación de su doctrina el saneamiento
del trópico.”

Robert F. Woodward, Esquire,
Deputy Assistant Secretary of State,
ARA - Department of State,
Washington, D. C.

The American delegation seems to have been one
of the proponents of this resolution, and the papers
here did full justice to its role as such.

div1.p:
I enclose an extra copy of this letter, which you
may wish to forward to Dr. Hench. Again, my sincere
thanks to him and to you for your good will and help.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, Harold M. Randall Chargé d'Affaires ad interim
Enclosure:
As stated above.
